Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with PC this last year Gleason 6 3+3. My family has urged me to get a second opinion on reading the biopsy slides. I have an appointment March 1 to have this second opinion with MO. Doing research I know this hospital has the 3T MRI. I have already had 2 biopsies with the first being negative. My next primary appointment isn't until March 21 and my next Urology appointment isn't till May. My first biopsy was pretty painless but second was quite painful. I don't relish the thoughts of having a biopsy every year so if it is necessary to continue them, I think it would be best for them to have access to this MRI to guide the biopsy. Can I have the opinions of those who have been through this. I sure appreciate all the information I have gleaned from this forum. Thanks to all
Posts.Signature: G6 3+3 5% 1/12 Age 67 PNBX #2 8-31-17 1-4-16 PSA 5.65 Right Base-Acute Chronic Inflamation/Glandular Atrophy 5-12-16 5.32 Right Lateral same 8-10-16 5.82 Right Middle Extensive glandular atrophy 3-14-17 6.75 free 22. Right Lateral Apex Adenocarcinoma G-6 3+3 5% 1/12 T1C 8-31-17 6.05 free 21.20 PNBX #1 2007 All negative 3-21-18 7.98 free 13.50
Posts.Title: 3t mri ?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider MRI imaging has a more prominent place in active surveillance than it did just a few years ago. Its a lot less invasive that the urologist shoving a cutting instrument into your keister for a biopsy, so its also a lot less likely to have side effects. I don't think you've mentioned where you're at, but if you're at an academic medical center, going for the MRI immediately instead of another biopsy at their suggestion makes pretty good sense. Thanks to all for your opinions on this. My second opinion is to be at UAMS Little Rock, AR which is next door to McClellan VA Hosp where I started my journey. Appreciate the advice. This is an excellent forum for gaining needed info. God Bless

Posts.Content: Hi Andy and Welcome. I too am on AS since Sept of 2017. VA has me coming back in for PSA checks every 6 months. My PSA is going up and May 1st my URO/Oncologist told me come back in 6 months and if still going up, then schedule another biopsy. In your case with PSA going down, there would not be a need for another biopsy. Your URO would be able to better advise. Stand by for others to reply also. Good Luck

Posts.Title: AS question

Posts.Content: Welcome to Cancer Forums, Littleman. I think the reason you have not received any response is that your husband has not has his appointment to discuss his biopsy results. We are not doctors, just people who have or affected by prostate cancer. The benign means no cancer in these cores. A Gleason score rates cancer from Gleason 6, lowest grade to Gleason 10 highest and most aggressive. Please don't jump to panic mode when you see this Gleason 7. It is only reported in 10% of one core so that means that cancer is present. More will respond as time goes on. This is not life threatning at this time, and no treatment is necessary immediately. When you meet with the urologist, he will be able to explain things a lot better. But for now, this is the time for you to research. All the sticky threads at the top will give you excellent advice on different treatments, biopsies etc. When you get the biopsy results, please do a signature that you can use on all posts. Also a second opinion will be suggested from Dr Epstein from John Hopkins. It would be good to know your husbands age and your location as the members in that area can recommend who to see for surgery, radiation treatments, etc. I am on Active Survellance, which means you are checked with more PSA test every 3 to 6 months, MRI;s and possibly MRI guided biopsy in the future. Best of luck on this journey. Again please don't panic as all of us have had the cancer diagnois also. We are here to help you. God Bless

Posts.Title: Interpretation of biopsy report

Posts.Content: On Mar 1 had second opinion on biopsy slides. Doc real nice and got my foot in door for UAMS if need RALP at some point. He gave same results as first reading which was not a surprise as the same docs work at UAMS. He also told me looked like they were treating me right and no surgery needed at this time. On Mar 21 had appointment with PCP with lab work up. Free PSA at 13.5 low and PSA at 7.98. So would almost bet they will want to do another biopsy when go to URO/Oncology appointment May 1. Not looking forward to that.

Posts.Content: Hello. I am seeking information for possible treatments down the road. I have read several of the threads on this forum and I'm glad I found one where I can get the info from those of you who have gone through this also. Under the advice of my doctor, I am waiting and watching for now. And while I am doing this, I would like all the info I can get as well as your educated opinions on which course of treatment is best for my circumstance. I feel like I am pretty well aware of the treatment options, but still value opinions on which options are best. Thanks to all in advance. I know with the stats so far, that I am low risk for now. I go back for follow up PSA and DRE first of May. Forgot to add BPH. No numbers but urologist says twice as large as normal.

Posts.Title: Active Survelliance

Posts.Content: I just had a MRI on Dec 12. They put me in head first and I was able to see outside that end. Of course they tell you not to move and they put something across the prostate area. Other than the hammering noise and a hard place on the table where my right arm was, nothing to it. I was in 45 minutes and closed my eyes and took a nap. Didn't even know when they injected the contrast thru the IV inside my elbow. So if you can get past the noise, you will do fine.

Posts.Content: Thanks for posting this. Reminds me of the song "And may all who come behind us, find us faithful". I have overcome the initial anexity over the initial diagnois. But what if and when they do another biopsy, will they find more. My first biopsy was painless but the second was quite painful. And my oncologist told me to expect another after I go back in October. Not fear maybe but dread. I will request the prostatic nerve block next time. Denis your journey and posts continue to inspire me along with countless others on this forum. Keep on keeping on inspiring others who find themselves diagnosed with prostate cancer.
